title: David Matthews (rugby union)
text:
David Joseph Matthews (17 April 1937 – 19 June 2019) was an English <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> flanker who played a record 502 games for <a href="Leicester%20Tigers">Leicester Tigers</a> from 1955 to 1974 as well as for <a href="Leicestershire%20Rugby%20Union">Leicestershire</a>, Midlands Counties (East) and the <a href="Barbarian%20F.C.">Barbarians</a>. At Leicester he was also a coach, director and was a life member.
Playing career.
Matthews joined Tigers direct from <a href="Oakham%20School">Oakham School</a> making his debut as an 18 year old on 3 September 1955 against <a href="Bedford%20Blues">Bedford</a> at <a href="Welford%20Road%20Stadium">Welford Road</a>. He took a while to establish himself in the club's first team playing only 9 matches over the next 2 seasons but became a regular in the 1957/58 season playing 32 games. Between 1961 and 1963 Matthews played in a record 109 successive games, including every game of 1961/62 and 1962/63 seasons. Matthews was the club's leading try scorer in 1962/63 with 11 tries and set a record for a forward in 1968/69 when he scored 21 tries in 43 games, this was Matthews third ever present season a club record. Matthews was club captain from 1965–1968. Matthews scored his 100th club try against <a href="Bristol%20Rugby">Bristol</a> at the <a href="Memorial%20Stadium%20%28Bristol%29">Memorial Ground</a> on 5 April 1969 and ended his career with 119 tries; a record for a forward until <a href="Neil%20Back">Neil Back</a> broke it in 2005. He broke the club's all-time appearance record against <a href="Broughton%20Park%20RUFC">Broughton Park</a> on 21 April 1973 with his 492-game and became the only player to make 500 appearances when he played against <a href="Northampton%20Saints">Northampton</a> on 23 February 1974.
Matthews played in three England trials in 1965–67 without gaining a cap but did face <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a> and, despite anti-apartheid protests, against the <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Springboks</a> with Midlands Counties (East).
Matthews' career lasted 18 years and 187 days, spanning 779 Tigers games in 19 seasons. On both counts this is the second longest Tigers career after <a href="Graham%20Willars">Graham Willars</a>.
In February 2011 Matthews was named 56th in Leicestershire's 100 Sporting Greats by the "<a href="Leicester%20Mercury">Leicester Mercury</a>".
Coaching and administration career.
Matthews was first team coach at Tigers from 1988–91 leading the side to the final of the <a href="1988-89%20Pilkington%20Cup">1988-89 Pilkington Cup</a>, where the side lost to <a href="Bath%20Rugby">Bath</a>. In 1997 Matthews became a non-executive director of <a href="Leicester%20Tigers">Leicester Tigers</a> serving until retiring in 2007. From 2001–03 Matthews was club president and in 2005 was awarded life membership.
